awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Experimental and numerical study on the Reynolds number dependence of surfaces in von Karman turbulent swirling flows
awd_abstract_narration:
The growth of surfaces, thought of as infinitely thin interfaces that separate regions occupied by fluids with dissimilar thermo-physical properties, is a process of intrinsic and practical interest with wide ranging applications in nature, science, and technical devices. As dissimilar fluids mix and interact proportionally to the area of the interface that separates them, the quantitative characterization of the rates of growth and destruction of surfaces is of critical importance. A comprehensive theory that describes these processes in turbulent flows, which are the most common flows encountered, is unavailable at present. The end goal of the project is to formulate a systematic theory that describes the dynamics of surfaces in turbulent flows depending on the state of the motion of the fluid. A comprehensive theory on the dynamics of surfaces will augment the general theory of turbulent flows, including flows with mixing and chemical reaction, which are found in chemical and energy conversion systems. In addition, our project will improve the understanding of physical processes observed in nature, such as cloud formation, where the evolution of interfaces is the rate limiting process. Thus, although the work is fundamental in nature, it has the potential for broad impacts in science and technology. The project will support the education of two graduate students, and it will also include significant outreach educational activities, which will focus on engaging grades 4-7 students in scientific discovery by investigating the properties of fluid mixing.

The overarching goal of the project is to quantify the dependence of the evolution of surfaces in turbulent flows on the Reynolds number. We combine direct numerical simulations and measurements in a novel von Karman turbulent swirling flow setup featuring a shear-driven closed flow between counter-rotating impellers with fully developed turbulence at high Reynolds numbers. The evolution of surfaces in this canonical laboratory flow is tracked quantitatively, while the parameters that describe the flow configuration are varied judiciously to probe a broad range of conditions in the parameter space where different effects are believed to play a role on the evolution of surfaces. The project will fill this broad goal by focusing on two thrusts: (i) Prove or disprove the Reynolds number dependence of the area and growth rates of large surfaces in turbulent flows; (ii) Identify the parameters that scale the evolution of surfaces in turbulent flow through a detailed analysis of the terms in the transport equation for surfaces in turbulence. The direct numerical simulations of the entire device include all geometrical complexities, while experiments feature a novel manner of generating surfaces on demand and state-of the art volumetric measurements of the velocity field and 3D representation of the turbulent. This novel and unique research program is unprecedented as it includes both the broadest range and highest Reynolds numbers ever considered in the study of surfaces in turbulent flows.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project is a collaborative research that combines numerical simulations and experiments. The overall goal of the projects is to identify the Reynolds number dependence of the statistics of large surfaces and of their growth and destruction rates, and to identify the flow parameters that allow to scale hydrodynamically the evolution of surfaces in canonical turbulent flows with mean shear. A collaborative research activity that combines state-of-the-art Direct Numerical Simulations (DNS) and experiments on the evolution of quasi-material surfaces in a series of von Karman swirling flows at high Reynolds numbers was conducted. This effort focuses on the experimental component. 

The experimental effort focuses on the development of a test apparatus to generate Von Karman swirling turbulent flows and its use to conduct measurements of turbulent propagating reacting fronts that are used as quasi-material interfaces of interest. Von Karman swirling turbulent flows are high-intensity turbulent flows generated between two rotating disks within a cylindrical enclosure. The benefit of using this flow configuration is that it gives access to high Reynolds number, high intensity turbulence with mean shear in a compact system that is suitable for laboratory studies across a broad range of conditions. By changing the rotation speed of the disks, chamber pressure and composition of the working fluid, a broad range of Reynolds number and turbulent scales can be generated at fixed integral length scale (determined by the rotating disk size).This system was used with reactive mixtures selected to maximize the Reynolds number while minimize non-idealities associated with thermo-diffusive (e.g., Lewis number effects) and hydrodynamic (e.g., density ratio effect) instabilities, and with well-characterize basic properties (e.g., propagation speed, density ratio, etc.). The selected mixtures are highly diluted, unity Lewis number H2/O2/He mixtures. Because the selected reactive mixtures are mixtures outside the range of validity of existing chemical mechanisms, an additional study of laminar flame speed measurements in a large, quasi-spherical combustion bomb was undertaken to gather experimental measurements for validating one of the existing chemical kinetics model. A validated chemical kinetics model is essential in the data reduction steps of the study (e.g., to compute laminar flame properties such as transport properties, density ratio, speed, etc.), but it was also used by the companion computational effort that relied on validated chemical kinetic mechanics for the condition of the experimental study. 

Measurements of turbulent propagating reacting fronts (premixed turbulent flames) over a range of Reynolds and Damkohler numbers, to span a significant portion of the Borghi-Peters or Reynolds-Damkohler planes were considered in the study. The results were used to establish the scaling relationship of turbulent reacting front propagation speed with Reynolds and Damkohler numbers. The study found that even at high Reynolds number, there remain a weak Reynolds number dependence, as well as a Damkohler number dependence that arises from the use of reacting fronts rather than truly passive ones.

Key achievements of the study are (1) the design, fabrication and use of the von Karman swirling turbulent flow apparatus; (2) the development of data reduction methodology to extract the propagation speed of turbulent reacting fronts and surface area from time history measurements of chamber pressure; and (3) the development of a scaling relation to determine the dependance of turbulent speed and turbulent surface area of turbulent fronts on Reynolds and Damkohler numbers. Measurements of the turbulent flame speed were used to deduce the scaling. The final result is a scaling relation with Reynolds and Damkohler that indicates that even in these high Reynolds number, high intensity turbulence flows there remain a dependence on the large scale Reynolds number on the propagation speed and surface area of propagating turbulent interfaces.

The contribution of this study is on the physics, description of properties and dynamics of turbulent interfaces. Fundamentally this is a problem rooted in turbulence physics. However, this is a problem that exists in many applied disciplines, such as chemical processing (mixing and chemical reaction), aerodynamics (turbulent and separated flows), energy conversion and propulsion systems (high efficiency, low emission turbulent combustion), atmospheric and oceanographic flows (turbulent transport, cloud formation and evolution, weather prediction) to name a few. The outcomes of this work further supports the foundational understanding of these processes and will inform new models of processes that fundamentally rely on turbulent transport. Turbulent combustion is a domain that will be directly and greatly impacted. Better description of the dynamics of interface is critical to describe premixed, partially-premixed and non-premixed turbulent combustion for application to high efficiency energy conversion systems that rely on significant pre-mixing and lean operation to lower pollutant emission and fuel burn.
